name: The Count of Monte Cristo
description: A classic adventure novel by Alexandre Dumas about betrayal, revenge, and redemption.

content.title: Synopsis
content.body: The Count of Monte Cristo is a tale of betrayal and justice. It follows the story of Edmond Dantès, a young sailor who is falsely accused of treason. Imprisoned for many years, he discovers the location of a hidden treasure on the island of Monte Cristo. Upon his escape, he embarks on a journey of vengeance against those who wronged him, assuming the identity of the eponymous Count.

content.title: Themes
content.body: Major themes in 'The Count of Monte Cristo' include justice vs revenge, the power of hope, the consequences of betrayal, and the complexities of human morality. The story also delves into the transformation of Dantès from a naïve sailor to a man driven by vengeance, and ultimately, his path to redemption.

content.title: Publication History
content.body: 'The Count of Monte Cristo' was originally published in serial form between 1844 and 1846 in the 'Journal des Débats' in France. Since then, it has been translated into many languages and adapted into numerous formats including abridged print editions, movies, and stage productions.

content.title: Legacy
content.body: The novel has left a profound impact on literature and popular culture, often cited as one of the greatest works of French literature. It has inspired numerous adaptations across various media, including films and television series, most notably the 1934 film and the 2002 movie. Its themes of justice and injustice continue to resonate with readers worldwide.
